body: Did you verify this build is not producing any new artifacts that will cause maven to complain when you build the java side from maven through the command line after running the .NET build in visual studio?

@dougmsft I wanted to take the simplest path to making this work across all projects, to do this I right clicked on every project and just made the upgrade to 451, this by itself did indeed generate some new artifacts that caused maven to complain due to the missing license issues for apache rat, I am guessing these artifacts are created by VS when the upgrade is done.  What do you think should we keep these new artifacts.  @markusweimer I will remove these other extraneous pieces, on your comment on whether the app.config for bridge.jar is needed I'll need to do some digging mostly because it was autogenerated as well when I right clicked on the project and made the upgrade to 451, my guess would be that it is indeed needed moving forward but I will verify.

Hmm, many unit tests keep failing on YARN.. @taegeonum do you want to take a look at the logs? ([DOWNLOAD LOGS HERE](https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B8aQK7AHF3r2bm9IenRDQ01xaWM)) Also, do the tests pass when you run them on YARN?

**P.S.** Note that I am running all my tests on YARN 2.7.3, and REEF was compiled with Hadoop 2.7.3 JARs
Ok, I've re-run REEF unit tests compiled with Hadoop 2.7.3 on our larger YARN 2.7.1 cluster, and they all consistently pass. Must be something with my 2.7.3 cluster setup.
Can you provide instructions on how to test this?
Sure - do you want this in the comments or as a readme in the code?

> Sure - do you want this in the comments or as a readme in the code?

Mail to the dev list would work. Also, maybe add it to the wiki?
I also updated the Tang project.

If the .NET build is generating new artifacts and they are necessary for .NET 4.5.1, then you need to keep them and update the Apache rat file. Since the maven build is first it is easy to miss this step.
Is it a good idea to camouflage potentially behavior-changing changes like adding `System.exit` under an innocent "Add TODO comment" title? Maybe it's better to have a more descriptive JIRA name?

I've added that System.exit() because we need it at the end of every
process that uses REEFEnvironment. I think the commit looks more consistent
with it, but I can split the JIRA into two or even three if you guys wish.

-- Sergiy.

On Tue, Mar 28, 2017 at 9:16 PM, Mariia Mykhailova <notifications@github.com
> wrote:

> Is it a good idea to camouflage potentially behavior-changing changes like
> adding System.exit under an innocent "Add TODO comment" title? Maybe it's
> better to have a more descriptive JIRA name?
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/apache/reef/pull/1278#issuecomment-289977538>, or mute
> the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAB6lM6vKrtPizBRnOkYXm4_UA7FUG02ks5rqdsZgaJpZM4MsDvS>
> .
>

I'm not suggesting to split the JIRA into several 1-liners, just to rename it so that it doesn't look like a comment-only change from the title. It is very counterintuitive to discover that a change called "Add TODO comment for all remaining System.exit() calls" actually adds a `System.exit()` call :-)

Makes sense. I will do it now

LGTM, will test and merge

@motus Owing to the assertion check codes you've added, I've found a bug in `NetworkServiceTest.testMultithreadedSharedConnMessagingNetworkServiceRate`.
When I running `NetworkServiceTest`, it throws assertion errors: 
```
java.lang.AssertionError
	at org.junit.Assert.fail(Assert.java:86)
	at org.junit.Assert.assertTrue(Assert.java:41)
	at org.junit.Assert.assertTrue(Assert.java:52)
	at org.apache.reef.io.network.NetworkServiceTest$MessageHandler.onNext(NetworkServiceTest.java:567)
	at org.apache.reef.io.network.NetworkServiceTest$MessageHandler.onNext(NetworkServiceTest.java:547)
	at org.apache.reef.io.network.impl.MessageHandler.onNext(NetworkService.java:202)
	at org.apache.reef.io.network.impl.MessageHandler.onNext(NetworkService.java:187)
	at org.apache.reef.wake.impl.SyncStage.onNext(SyncStage.java:93)
	at org.apache.reef.wake.remote.transport.netty.AbstractNettyEventListener.channelRead(AbstractNettyEventListener.java:68)
	at org.apache.reef.wake.remote.transport.netty.NettyChannelHandler.channelRead(NettyChannelHandler.java:66)
	at io.netty.channel.AbstractChannelHandlerContext.invokeChannelRead(AbstractChannelHandlerContext.java:333)
	at io.netty.channel.AbstractChannelHandlerContext.fireChannelRead(AbstractChannelHandlerContext.java:319)
	at io.netty.channel.ChannelInboundHandlerAdapter.channelRead(ChannelInboundHandlerAdapter.java:86)
	at org.apache.reef.wake.remote.transport.netty.ChunkedReadWriteHandler.channelRead(ChunkedReadWriteHandler.java:102)
	at io.netty.channel.AbstractChannelHandlerContext.invokeChannelRead(AbstractChannelHandlerContext.java:333)
	at io.netty.channel.AbstractChannelHandlerContext.fireChannelRead(AbstractChannelHandlerContext.java:319)
	at io.netty.handler.codec.MessageToMessageDecoder.channelRead(MessageToMessageDecoder.java:103)
	at io.netty.channel.AbstractChannelHandlerContext.invokeChannelRead(AbstractChannelHandlerContext.java:333)
	at io.netty.channel.AbstractChannelHandlerContext.fireChannelRead(AbstractChannelHandlerContext.java:319)
	at io.netty.handler.codec.ByteToMessageDecoder.channelRead(ByteToMessageDecoder.java:163)
	at io.netty.channel.AbstractChannelHandlerContext.invokeChannelRead(AbstractChannelHandlerContext.java:333)
	at io.netty.channel.AbstractChannelHandlerContext.fireChannelRead(AbstractChannelHandlerContext.java:319)
	at io.netty.channel.DefaultChannelPipeline.fireChannelRead(DefaultChannelPipeline.java:787)
	at io.netty.channel.nio.AbstractNioByteChannel$NioByteUnsafe.read(AbstractNioByteChannel.java:125)
	at io.netty.channel.nio.NioEventLoop.processSelectedKey(NioEventLoop.java:511)
	at io.netty.channel.nio.NioEventLoop.processSelectedKeysOptimized(NioEventLoop.java:468)
	at io.netty.channel.nio.NioEventLoop.processSelectedKeys(NioEventLoop.java:382)
	at io.netty.channel.nio.NioEventLoop.run(NioEventLoop.java:354)
	at io.netty.util.concurrent.SingleThreadEventExecutor$2.run(SingleThreadEventExecutor.java:116)
	at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:745)
```
But, the test passed because the assertion is not executed in main thread. 
I've investigated it and found that this is because the expected number of messages is wrong in `MessageHandler`. I've created an issue for this ([REEF-1762](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-1762)), and PR for it (#1281). 

Could you please take a look at #1281 first? I would want #1281 to be merged before this PR is merged.
Good catch @taegeonum! I wonder why I did not see this error. Anyway, I've just merged your fix into the master so you can merge mine 😄

Thanks Julia for the comments. I have published a new version.

I tried the build on my machine, but was not successful:

```
> dotnet restore .\Org.Apache.Reef.DotNet.sln

Restoring packages for Org.Apache.REEF.Utilities\Org.Apache.Reef.Utilities.DotNet.csproj...
C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\1.0.0\NuGet.targets(97,5): error : Unable to resolve 'NETStandard.Library (>= 2.0.0-beta-25123-01)' for '.NETStandard,Version=v2.0'. [Org.Apache.Reef.DotNet.sln]
```

I seem to have the right version of the `dotnet` tooling:

```
> dotnet

Microsoft .NET Core Shared Framework Host

  Version  : 2.0.0-preview1-001913-00
  Build    : d52f51f6a71001560b06d44b11a428ede4ddef5f
```

I get the same error when trying to build from VS 2017.

Thanks Markus, I am not able to repro the error that you are seeing. I tried both with the installer and zip with the preview1 version that you are using.

This directory is weird:
`C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\1.0.0\NuGet.targets`

Looking at my install, I don't have an sdk\1.0.0 -- did you have an older install of dotnet before installing this one? You may need to uninstall all versions of dotnet core from the machine and then install the latest bits. 

If that doesn't work, here are a couple of things to try:
1) Did you call the following before building? And if so, did that succeed?
`dotnet restore Org.Apache.Reef.DotNet.sln`
2) Can you try testing the dotnet binaries by creating a test directory and typing 
`dotnet new library`

Also I found that all management of dotnet installs comes down to what gets installed in Program Files\dotnet. So if  you have older versions and you have uninstalled them. I would double check if you still have a Program Files\dotnet folder -- if so, then delete it. Then install the latest version and that should clear up any older files.
Just wondering is it the right way to keep multiple versions?  What are the blocking issues if we officially move to the new version?

> Just wondering is it the right way to keep multiple versions? What are the blocking issues if we officially move to the new version?

We've discussed this on the devlist a few times. This PR is part of that plan of record.
@markusweimer  Looks like the replication doesn't work as the change is shown together with a new PL I am trying to submit.

Markus - were you able to get building?

Julia - I dont think we will need to keep two separate versions of newtonsoft. However in case that we do (say the version of Avro we are using is not compatible with newer version of netwonsoft), we do have the ability to specify assemblies for different platforms. Since Netwonsoft 10 contains both dotnet core and .net framework binaries, Im just including that across the board.

23-01)' for '.NETStandard,Version=v2.0'. [D:\src\reef\lang\cs\Org.Apache.Reef.DotNet.sln]

> Do we need to add the binary file? Or can we generate it during builds?

Yes we can, but the solution involves codegen for the avro classes from schema. However, the generated classes don't have appropriate licenses and they will generate rat.txt in the target. Therefore it is a little bit convoluted.

> Yes we can, but the solution involves codegen for the avro classes from parquet schema. However, the generated classes don't have appropriate licenses and they will generate rat.txt in the target. Therefore it is a little bit convoluted.

The generated classes would not have to pass RAT, would they? I mean, they only exist at runtime?

In any case: How big is the test file? My main concern is to keep the repository small and tidy :)

>How big is the test file? My main concern is to keep the repository small and tidy :)

It's 1 KB.

>>How big is the test file? My main concern is to keep the repository small and tidy :)
> It's 1 KB.

Ah, nevermind, then.

Yes, that happens when you rebase before pushing. During a code review, it is often easier to just put new commits to the branch under review.

Thanks for the review!

Will test and merge.

@andrey-me I have addressed your review comments. Please have another look. 
I already have a test TestMetricsMessage. I use it to test whenever I made any change.
I completed a pass.

@markusweimer I am afraid that PR does not solve the problem. It adds a a few methods like `.isClosed()` and writes more info to the log, but never actually closes the message dispatcher. E.g. right now I see a thread running at the end of `HelloREEFYarnUnmanagedAM` example:
```
2017-04-14 11:29:44,176 FINEST reef.util.ThreadLogger.logThreads main | Threads running after DriverLauncher.close():
        TG main THREAD EvaluatorMessageDispatcher:container_1492031281343_0010_01_000001:pool-14:thread-001 :: WAITING, Alive, NOT interrupted, NOT daemon
                sun.misc.Unsafe.park(Native Method)
                java.util.concurrent.locks.LockSupport.park(LockSupport.java:186)
                java.util.concurrent.locks.AbstractQueuedSynchronizer$ConditionObject.await(AbstractQueuedSynchronizer.java:2043)
                java.util.concurrent.LinkedBlockingQueue.take(LinkedBlockingQueue.java:442)
                java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.getTask(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1068)
                java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1130)
                java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:615)
                java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:724)
```
It is exactly because of that thread we need to call `System.exit()` explicitly.

I am inclined to close that PR without merging and accept the same changes along with those that would actually close the leftover threads.

**P.S.** @shouhengyi-microsoft you can look at the earlier PR #1268 from @taegeonum to see how to close the thread pool gracefully. (We will still need your logging fixes in case we fail, though)

**Update:** it looks like the problem is actually much easier - we just have to make sure we call `EvaluatorMessageDispatcher.close()` on all execution paths. According to the logs, it's never being called.

**Update 2:** I think I've found an earlier attempt to fix that issue: see PR #1241 I believe that the problem described in the comments to that PR has been already solved in subsequent PRs. I will reapply that update to the current master to check if it works now.

The problems reported in the comments above now seem to be gone as they have been fixed in other PRs. Reopening to see how it will fare on our CI servers.

**NOTE:** This PR should take priority over #1270, which, in turn, should be closed and its changes pushed under another JIRA issue. See discussion at #1270 for more details.

@jwang98052 Do you have any more comments? If not, could you please merge this PR? (and maybe look at #1241 after it? 😄)
Thank you!

looks good to me

I will test and merge.
As per our discussion today, let's close this PR in favor of #1241. @shouhengyi-microsoft could you please close it? Thank you!
@markusweimer I modified my PR and it's ready for review. Thanks.

> Why would we depend on a different version of hadoop-core than hadoop?

I found hadoop version is different from hadoop-core version in maven repo. From maven central repo [1], the latest hadoop-core version is 1.2.1.

[1] http://search.maven.org/#search%7Cgav%7C1%7Cg%3A%22org.apache.hadoop%22%20AND%20a%3A%22hadoop-core%22

Otherwise it's ready for review.
@motus I made an separate JIRA ticket to address adding additional logging. It's ready for review.
Are you sure we need `hadoop-core` and not `hadoop-common`? There really should be only one version of Hadoop we depend on.

> Are you sure we need hadoop-core and not hadoop-common? There really should be only one version of Hadoop we depend on.

I removed `hadoop-core` in the java project and the `reef-experiment` built. However tests failed in the .Net side.
How did they fail? What is the error message? Maybe we need to depend on something else, but `hadoop-core` doesn't seem to even be built by current versions of Hadoop's code base anymore.

I agree that including hadoop-core 1.2.1 seems very strange. However I didn't have any success without it. I removed hadoop-core 1.2.1 from the project and it gave me this exception:
```
Exception in thread "main" java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: org/apache/hadoop/fs/Path
        at org.apache.reef.experimental.parquet.ParquetReader.<init>(ParquetReader.java:65)
        at org.apache.reef.experimental.parquet.ParquetReader.main(ParquetReader.java:187)
Caused by: java.lang.ClassNotFoundException: org.apache.hadoop.fs.Path
        at java.net.URLClassLoader.findClass(Unknown Source)
        at java.lang.ClassLoader.loadClass(Unknown Source)
        at sun.misc.Launcher$AppClassLoader.loadClass(Unknown Source)
        at java.lang.ClassLoader.loadClass(Unknown Source)
        ... 2 more
```
`Path` is used in a constructor with [Injection].
This class [seems to have moved](http://search.maven.org/#search%7Cga%7C1%7Cg%3A%22org.apache.hadoop%22%20AND%20fc%3A%22org.apache.hadoop.fs.Path%20%22) to `hadoop-common`.

In my IntelliJ, without hadoop-core 1.2.1, I can `import org.apache.hadoop.fs.Path;` and compile with no problem. I believe my code is using `Path` in `hadoop-common`. I did clean and update my project by the way. However, once I run the main, it throws `java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError` exceptions.

It is because of this?
```
        <dependency>
            <groupId>org.apache.hadoop</groupId>
            <artifactId>hadoop-common</artifactId>
            <version>${hadoop.version}</version>
            <scope>provided</scope> <=======?
        </dependency>
```
Yes, "provided" means that the jar will be used for compilation but not packaged in the shaded jar. In general, it is assumed to be present in the classpath of the runtime system.
I took out `<scope>provided</scope>`, did `mvn clean install -U` and ran the main. It still gave me the same exception. Will this be a problem?

By default, the scope is "compile". You can read more about mvn scopes here:
https://maven.apache.org/guides/introduction/introduction-to-dependency-mechanism.html
You get the exception because your app does not find the hadoop-common jar in the classpath at runtime. (but it was present at compile time). That is, you have to fix your runtime classpath.

Hmm, the same error:
```text
Failed tests: 
  FailTaskTest.testFailTaskStop:86->failOn:52 Unexpected error: java.util.concurrent.RejectedExecutionException: Task java.util.concurrent.FutureTask@5acfb476 rejected from java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor@7a50dd8d[Terminated, pool size = 0, active threads = 0, queued tasks = 0, completed tasks = 8]
```
I will investigate, but I am inclined to think that this is benigh, and can happen during shutdown. We just have to log it properly instead of failing.
In that case, can I remove the `hadoop-core` dependency and close this PR and the JIRA?
I think so. But before you do it, try to construct the right classpath and make sure you are able to run your app
OK, this new commit seems to fix the issues. All unit tests pass locally and on YARN, but please dear reviewer try it on your machine, too.
@jwang98052, can you have a look at this?
@motus @andrey-me I have addressed your review comments. As there is a conflict for the merge, I also rebased it  with the master. Thanks!
Without building for .NET Standard 2.0, the build succeeds. Hence, the issue seems to be the lack of a `TraceListener` class (and related classes) in .NET Standard.
I completed a pass.

I played around a bit and added the following to `Org.Apache.REEF.Utilities.DotNet.csproj`:

```xml
  <ItemGroup Condition=" '$(TargetFramework)' == 'netstandard2.0' ">
    <PackageReference Include="Microsoft.Extensions.Logging" Version="1.1.1" />
    <PackageReference Include="Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Console" Version="1.1.1" />
    <PackageReference Include="Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Debug" Version="1.1.1" />
    <PackageReference Include="Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.TraceSource" Version="1.1.1" />
  </ItemGroup>
```
That got me a few steps further:

```
1>ByteUtilities.cs(21,47,21,53): error CS0234: The type or namespace name 'Binary' does not exist in the namespace 'System.Runtime.Serialization.Formatters' (are you missing an assembly reference?)
1>Diagnostics\DefaultUnhandledExceptionHandler.cs(49,52,49,79): error CS0246: The type or namespace name 'UnhandledExceptionEventArgs' could not be found (are you missing a using directive or an assembly reference?)
```

`System.Runtime.Serialization.Formatters` is actually available as a NuGet for .NET Standard 2.0, but doesn't include the `Binary` type.
@jwang98052 Thanks! I answered :)

I am not able to reproduce these errors, its sound like you almost have an older version of dot net as I saw something similar when building with .net 1.1 a while back. Are you building in VS or command line?

Binary is supported in .net standard 2.0:
https://apisof.net/catalog/System.Runtime.Serialization.Formatters.Binary

So the duplicate Utilities project may have been causing an issue - it was meant to be a rename of the file. Anyhow that has been resolved.

Let me try creating a VM with VS2017 and dotnet cli installed to see if I can get the same results.

> Are you building in VS or command line?

I build in VS 2017.

I have `1.0.3` and `2.0.0-preview1-005807` in `C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk`. When I run `dotnet build` from the command line, I get the same complaints from the build. `dotnet --version` prints `2.0.0-preview1-005807`.
LGTM, will test and merge.
@markusweimer  I removed hadoop-core dependency and modified my PR according to the previous comments. It's ready for review. Thanks.

Ok that is interesting. Maybe we need to discuss this over voice. Here is what I have done:
1) Installed Server 2016 on Azure VM
2) Installed dot-net cli tools using the installer (same version as what you are using). 
3) Installed VS2017

Then going to command prompt under the dev\lang\cs directory, I type the following:
1) dotnet restore Org.Apache.REEF.DotNet.sln
2) dotnet build Org.Apache.REEF.DotNet.sln

It builds sucessfully with 502 warnings -- I am not building through VS.

I also noticed that if I tried building without VS2017 installed, however that fails due to the missing windows SDK that gets installed with VS.
Correction on the dotnet version - I am using 005823, not 5807.
LGTM, will merge.

Aha! I am able to reproduce when I build in VS2017 and then build on the command line. So in this case we can't fix building in VS as VS uses a different version of dotnet than what we are calling from the command line which is what causes the build error. This should be fixed in a later release of VS.

To test this on your end, clean the repro (git clean -xdf), then try calling git restore, git build on the command line. That ended up working for me.
